Of those stores, the ones that we actually closed rather than ones that we've redeveloped made GBP 2.1 million of profit.
So they weren't unprofitable, but they were all getting very close to the edge.
When a store is making sort of around GBP 100,000, GBP 200,000 and relatively low percentage, we take the view, at lease end, that we'll close it.
We're not going to wait for those stores to make a loss.
What this doesn't account for is the fact that just as when we open stores, we will pick up or we'll lose sales elsewhere.
Sort of when you close stores, you get a little bit of reverse cannibalization as well.
But I think what this stresses is: one, our willingness to close stores; and two, the rates at which we can close stores.
The fact that we closed 13 in just a half year is reflective of that.
And what it all comes down to is the flexibility of our store portfolio.
This graph shows the amounts of -- the percentage of our leases by value that will have expired after a given number of years.
What you can see is that within just under 6 years, half our leases will have expired.
And within 10 years, over 70% of our leases will have expired.
So we do have a lot of flexibility in terms of our ability to resize and renegotiate our lease portfolio.

Moving -- coming back from the brief tour from the really bad news, retail profit's down 33%, combination of declining like-for-likes, poorer markdown and some one-off cost increases in the cost base such as national living wage and rents review.
In terms of margin movement, slight attrition in bought-in gross margin.
This was down to a change in freight rates.
International freight rates have moved up a little bit over the last 6 months.
Markdown cost us 0.5%.
And what you can see is that actually, all things being equal, with 6% less stock going into the end of season sale, you would expect markdown sale -- you would expect our clearance rates to improve.
The less stock you have going into a sale, the more likely you are -- the bigger percentage of it you normally clear.
That didn't happen, and the markdown sales were down 14%.
That's cost us a lot of money.
It cost us about GBP 11 million.
The reasons for that, we think, are threefold, although we're unsure as to the balance, as to which reason is worth how much.
But the 3 reasons are as follows.
First of all, we were trying to clear the stock that we knew wasn't right in the first place.
Most of this stock was quarter -- stock that we'd introduced into our stores in quarter 1, and we knew that those ranges weren't right.

Secondly, although we had our sale at exactly the same time as last year, relative to the rest of the market, we looked late and later than usual because a lot of our key competitors move their sales forward.
Next year, we'll move our sale forward by at least 1 week.
The third reason, and I think this is the most important and difficult to gauge, is that we think our ability to clear stock in end-of-season sales is beginning to reduce.
And the reason for that is because of all the good work we've done in clearing stock on our clearance -- through our clearance website.
So at any time of the year now, customers can go on to our website, click on the Offers tab, and they will be able to get access to last season's sales stock.
That -- over the years, that has had a huge effect in helping us improve our markdown.
But I think it's beginning to catch up with us in the stores now.
Those customers who would have queued up at 5:00 in the morning are actually thinking, "I won't get up 5:00 in the morning, I'll go on the website once it's sold back online."
So in recognition of that, we've assumed in our forecasts that our clearance rates at the end of season will also be down on last year.
So achieved gross margin, down 0.6%.
Store payroll, this, you won't necessarily have been expecting.
Store payroll actually went down faster than sales.
And this is all about the efficiency measures that we've introduced into the stores.
Had we done nothing, then the increase -- inflationary costs in wages would have meant that wages would have been about 0.6% -- would have had a 0.6% adverse impact on margin.
The balance of 0.8% is all about all the work we've done to improve the efficiency of staffing in our stores.
And a lot of that is about the introduction of new systems, the development of our shift marketplace.
We've rewritten our [road training] program.
We've changed the bonus system used for delivery and behind-the-scenes, changed the bonus system used for replenishment.
And all of those small improvements added together have given us a significant benefit in the year.
Store occupancy costs, big adverse movement.
This is all about negative like-for-likes.
Underlying rental inflation at review is 0.
Warehousing and distribution, no increases in actual picking costs or cost per units.
Again, this is about deleveraging over fixed overheads.
Central overheads, exactly the same effect.

These are the product teams, HR, finance, and drop in sales meant that -- their drop in sales hasn't been matched by drop in costs, which has given us a sort of GBP 5 million, GBP 6 million increase in relative costs.
Overall margin movement of minus 3.5%.

So we're expecting that 2.9% attrition in margin for the full year.
So expecting margins of around 11.8% for the full year, 14.7% -- as against 14.7% last year.
Directory, very different picture.
Sales, up 5.7%.
Full price sales up 7.4%.

sales were up 3%.

and LABEL.

is the rent problems that we had.

was minus 7 and moved to minus 1 in the third -- in the second quarter.

customer base, 6% increase overseas.

In terms of margin movements, margins edged forward 0.1% in Directory.

business.

Photography and catalogs.

Central overheads.

Moving on to the outlook.

Three things to talk about: retail profitability and how we see our stores moving forward; secondly, an update on the progress we've made in terms of improving Directory, systems and marketing; and thirdly, a little bit about the consumer environment.
Starting with the trickiest one, retail.
And the question I think we've got to ask ourselves and certainly has been asked generally is, are retail shops an asset or a liability?
Now there are those who take the view, an understandable view, that retail shops are a millstone around any retailer's neck, and they will drag them down into oblivion.
We don't share that view.
And whilst we recognize that our retail business is likely to decline in turnover and profit, we still think it's an asset rather than a liability.
So it's an asset with a declining value, but nonetheless an asset.
We don't think it will ever be a drain on the company's resources.
So a decline in financial value, but at the same time, and this is something that's very difficult to quantify in terms of money, it is becoming an increasing asset to our Directory business.
And we see it as an intrinsic part of the online service that we offer.
And it's interesting that even companies like Amazon are beginning to have a physical presence.

So whilst we can't be sure as to what's going to happen in retail, we are fairly confident that in one form or another, not necessarily in the same shape or size or cost as they are today, there will be some form of retail presence for clothing shops going forward.
What I'm going to do now is just develop the narrative that we started to talk about 6 months ago, which I know you all found absolutely riveting, and you're going to be delighted to come back to it.
This is a graph that shows the profitability of our stores.
You'll all be familiar with this because you saw it last time.
What happens to the profitability of our portfolio in the event that we have 3 different scenarios over the next 10 years: minus 2% like-for-like growth, minus 4%, minus 6%.
And you can see the profitability, as we said last time, would be 19%, 15% and 10%.

And the assumptions we've made on that, although we won't open any new space, that unprofitable stores are closed on or around lease expiry and that profitable stores are held over at the end of their lease.
So we wouldn't necessarily renew them for any period of time, but we would just hold over at the passing rent without any rent reductions.
And certainly, in today's environment, that is, in many case, the worst case.
Normally, we'd get better than that.
And the other thing to bear in mind is that 70% of our leases, as I said before, will expire within 10 years.
Developing that a little bit further, let's go to that bottom scenario.
And I would like to just stress, because whenever you do these things, they will think that whatever you put up on the screen is your forecast.
This is our worst case scenario, not our forecast for the business.
But our worst-case scenario is that at that minus 6% compound annual decline in sales, that stores would generate a net branch contribution before central overheads of around GBP 100 million of cash.
That begs the question, could they support the central overheads of the business?
And I just want to go into how we see the central overheads being managed were this scenario to play out.
At the moment, the central overheads of the business are around GBP 230 million.
This is -- these are cash costs.
So they -- doesn't include depreciation, does include an allowance, GBP 16 million allowance for maintenance.
And if we break that down into the constituent parts.
It's GBP 40 million in marketing, GBP 50 million in warehousing, GBP 60 million of distribution and GBP 80 million of central overheads.
These are largely the departments that are shared with Directory, such as our product departments, HR departments.
Within each one of those areas, there is actually quite a lot of variable costs.
If we pick less in our warehouses, we'll spend less money on pickers.
If we have fewer stores, then marketing costs will come down because a lot of that cost are window dressers.
Fewer stores, fewer windows, fewer window dressers.
If we say the minus 6% scenario would give us a drop in sales of 57%, the reason that that's more, I can see instantly you've all added it up, 6% compound, couldn't possibly come to minus 57%.
The reason that it comes to more than that is because of the store closures.
But if we model that drop in sales and say, well, what variable costs would automatically drop out of the business, it will be around 20% drop in those central overheads.

If we assume, as it has done this year, that Directory grows as much as retail declines, then the cost that retail pays for the central overheads will decline, but that will be paid for by the growth in the Directory business.
And put it another way, you would still need those central costs to run the Directory business whether or not you had a retail business.
It's just, in a way, the subsidy that retail will pay will come down.
If you take out those shared costs, all the costs will be reallocated toward Directory, they drop to about 22%.
Further cost savings, we think, can get at around 6%.
These are sort of semi-variable costs.
Things like our retail hubs.
Some of the leases will expire over the next 10 years.
We won't just renew them in the same shape and size, and in fact, we're already looking at plans to consolidate 2 hubs into one which will save us significant amount of money.
So overall, we get to around 52% of the central overheads.
That's around GBP 120 million of cost.
Model that across the entire portfolio, and this is -- these are making allowances for 2 things.

First of all, continued spend of capital on cosmetics, still spending GBP 16 million a year all the way through on cosmetics, and also assuming that wages continue to grow faster than inflation by around 1%.
Put those together, you end up with cash flow of around GBP 1 billion.
So when we're thinking about sort of asset or liability, we think actually, even in this worst case scenario, asset of GBP 1 billion.
If you look at the minus 2%, that GBP 1 billion would come to around GBP 2 billion.
So we think the retail portfolio, as an asset to the businesses, were in terms of future cash flow somewhere between GBP 1 billion and GBP 2 billion.
And you can all go through and discount that at the rates you like and come to sort of nitty gritty valuation, which I'm sure we'll enjoy.
However, it's not quite the whole story because some of the assumptions we've made are definitely not right.
First of all, we will open new stores; and secondly, we will -- are more than likely, in an environment of minus 6% like-for-like sales, to experience some rent reductions.
Taking each one of those in turn.
And I feel I have re-explain this many, many times because it is so counterintuitive.
People say, "Why on earth are you opening stores in an environment of declining like-for-like sales?"
And it's a very good question.
And the reason we're opening stores is because the stores we're opening have a quick payback and high profit.
And if we take a store, and this is what we do now, it's a discipline when we open new stores, and say, let's model the minus 6% on the new store that we opened.
So let's take a store, and for ease, say, we invest GBP 1 million in the capital expenditure on that store.
With a 24-month payback, and I should say our 24-month payback assumes 0 like-for-likes, so actually flat, [FX] going down, it would be slightly more than 24 months.
But that means in year 1, you would expect to get cash out of that store of GBP 0.5 million.

Model the cash forward, and you'd expect -- and this is on the basis of a minus 6% like-for-like scenario in that chart, you would expect to get 2.5% -- sorry, GBP 2.5 million back for your GBP 1 million investment.
So as counterintuitive though it is to invest in a store with a declining profit, in cash terms, it's actually a good investment.
And if I put it in another way, if I said, "I've got a bond, and the bond will pay you 50% interest in year 1, but in year 10 will only pay you 4%," you would all buy instantly.
So -- and that is the way that we look at these stores.
We're taking very, very few stores in more than 10-year leases.
Incidentally, the internal rate of return on the money invested in that, if you take the model, run an IRR on it, it comes to around 34%.
So really healthy use of the businesses' capital.
And obviously, the more of these stores were opening, the more of that central overhead we are also recovering.
The second thing is rent reductions.
We have come to the end of 8 stores.
Remember that we closed 10 stores at the end of their lease; another 8, we renewed.
If we look at the rent on those 8 stores, the rent before was GBP 2.9 million; after, GBP 2.2 million.
I should say that GBP 2.2 million accounts for any capital contribution amortizing over the life of the lease.
So that takes the rent to sales in those stores from 9.5% to 7%.
In addition, with open concessions in those stores of around -- which will generate rental income of around GBP 175,000, that's mainly cafés.
That takes the rent-to-sales ratio to 6.5%.
The capital required to maintain a lease -- we normally do go back and spend some capital to maintain a shop, but the average lease length of these renewals is around 7 years.
And the profitability of the stores that we'd renewed on once we've renewed -- reviewed the rent is 23%.

So again, the assumption in our model that we won't get rent reductions certainly in an environment of minus 6% like-for-like, all our experience suggests that, that isn't right and that we would see rent reductions.
I'm just going to talk a little bit about that concession number of GBP 175,000.
At the moment, the vast majority of our concessions are small cafés.
They generate quite a lot of rent, around GBP 4.5 million, GBP 5 million of rent for the group.
But the main purpose is to make the stores more enjoyable places that people want to go.
In Arndale, we're introducing a whole range of different concessions to see what effect they have and whether they're successful or not.

Now as the Chairman said at the beginning, we're a business that likes to try things in a small way, see if they work, don't assume all of these work and suddenly every next door is going to have a hairdresser and a gym and a restaurant, they won't.
But we are going to try all of these things to see 2 things.
One is do they pay the rent, do they make money?
And the second is, can they enhance the look and feel of the store to make them places that people are more likely to want to go?
In terms of restaurants, I should just say we've done a deal with a company called International Restaurants Group, which is basically a Gino D’Acampo brand restaurant.
We'll be opening 2 of those stores: 1 in Manchester, 1 in Hull.
And the profit that they'll make for NEXT, we estimated being around GBP 300,000.
So not a lot of profit, that's a 50% share of the profit of those restaurants.
And the real thing is not the profit they make, it's what effect they have on the shop.
So that's all I'm going to say about retail.
I think I'll finish by saying that the retail business, whilst it may make less money going forward, we don't think it will make a loss.
And as long as it doesn't make a loss, we have to recognize that it does provide an enormous benefit to Directory.
More than 40% of our orders by value are collected from store, and that's by value.
In terms of actual numbers of orders, it's more than that, because the average order value going to store is lower.
So more than 50% of the customers ordering from NEXT choose to have their stock delivered to a store.
80% of our returns come back through stores.
Now you might think, well, returns are a bad thing.
If we shut the stores, we'd get less returns.
We would get less returns, but we'd also sell less stock in the first place because the confidence that you can return stock is very important.
You might also ask, and it'd be good question, why the difference between the 50% collect from the store and 80% return to store.
And the answer is that you have to be in for -- to do a return.
You don't necessarily have to be in for a delivery.
The delivery driver can leave it safe, they can leave it in your porch, they can leave it with your neighbor.
And final thing is that 15% of our -- the customers we recruit for Directory, we recruit through our stores.
And I should -- I suppose I can't stress this enough, the stores are a huge asset to Directory, but we don't put any financial value on it at all within our retail accounts.
In terms of Directory modernization, this -- it's taken a long time.
We started this process 18 months ago.
We brought in a huge number of systems.
We changed a large number of people.
We'd employed a lot of new people.
And the benefits are just beginning to come through into our sales numbers, really sort of from March onwards.
If you look back, those are brand sales by month.
We've grouped March and April together because Easter moved between the 2 of them.
But you can see broadly an upward slope.
If you break that down into retail and Directory, you can see that the acceleration in Directory growth has been far, far higher than the acceleration in retail growth.
We think the retail growth, a lot of that was about better weather in June and July.
So you shouldn't get too excited about that.
The Directory acceleration, there's definitely a weather effect there as well.
And we could see on days that were suddenly warm in June and July, they got huge boost in sales, don't underestimate that.
But there is, we believe, something more going on.
Just running through some of the investments we've made.
We've invested around GBP 5.5 million in new proprietary software.
These systems, I think, are like a web merchandising system.
This allows us to deliver different content to different customers at any one point in time.

We bought a database analytics program that allows us to segment our customers more effectively; content management system that allows us to deliver far more content to our website with much less labor.
At the moment, the -- or rather historically, the process of producing different [pieces] created for our Directory was extremely cumbersome and took a lot of labor.
With the data management platform, this allows us to selectively serve different adverts to our customers or customers that we recognize through a cookie on third-party websites and social media.
So this will allow us to do that thing that --- where you look at something on a website, and then it follows you around to other places.
It allows us to do that.
We won't necessarily do it that crudely.

[Obviously,] it would be more effective to show people things that were like the thing that they looked at but didn't buy rather than the thing they looked at and didn't buy, but we'll see about that.

Invested quite a lot of money in security, and we have bought a new credit platform that allows us -- we're not using this yet, but it will allows us going forward to introduce new credit offers for our customers beyond the traditional Directory account.
Of that GBP 5.5 million, around GBP 4.5 million was spent in -- or will be spent in the current year.
And within our forecasts, that's all written off as a revenue cost.
In terms of people, we've taken on 110 -- 121 new people.
Lion's share of that is in development and data, but we've also taken on additional content people, people -- additional people to design new flows through our website.
And we've also invested in security and testing stuff to make sure that our systems are robust.
In many ways, we would have liked to take on more people.
The constraint there, I should stress, hasn't been money, it's just -- gets to the point where taking on too many people actually begins to have a negative effect.
So we've got -- we can't take on people at such a rate of speed that we have a lot of untrained, unmanaged people in the business who don't know what they're doing.
So we will see that number, I think, creeping up over the next 2 or 3 years.
Those add about GBP 6.5 million of additional cost.
GBP 12 million of total costs added to the Directory cost base through software and people.
The reason that's a GBP 1 million more than the GBP 11 million we told you at our last report is because GBP 1 million of that was spent last year on software.
Just in terms of a few of the things that we improved.
We've now rolled out our mobile site across all handsets and via all methods of access.
So we have a fully adaptive site.
Whether you come through Google or go through next.co.uk, you'll be served with our mobile site.
27% -- in January 2016, 27% of orders came by mobile, with a conversion rate of 4.2%.
38% at the moment and with a conversion rate of 5.3%.
That's an improvement of 26%.

I should stress that the orders participation, going from 26% to 38%, would probably have happened anyway because more and more people are ordering online and ordering through their mobile sets anyway.
The improvement in conversion rate wouldn't have happened without the improvements that we've made.
Please don't make the mistake that we initially made when we saw this number, thinking, "Hey, we're going to increase our sales by 26% on all those customers."
An improvement in conversion rate is always balanced to some extent by a reduction in the number of times the customer comes back to the site.
Often, when people fail to buy something, they will come back and have another bash at it.
So it's not quite as good as it looks.
In terms of NextUnlimited.
Remember, we talked about this before.
This is where we deliver -- you get a year's unlimited free deliveries to home from an upfront charge of GBP 20.
The cost of that in the current year, we think, will be around GBP 5 million of lost delivery income.
And that will -- at the moment, more than 10% of our orders are being delivered free-to-home because of NextUnlimited.
And the sales increase we're getting from the customers that have Unlimited is more than enough to pay for the GBP 5 million of cost, of lost handling charge.
But it does mean long term, we'll see margins -- hopefully, sales moving up but margins moving down as a result of less delivery income.
It is worth noting that with more than 50% of our orders going through stores, at the moment, more than 60% of the orders NEXT customers make, in one way or another, are going to them without charge.
We rebranded our account NEXT Pay.
Remember, we were very worried 2 years ago about our credit business.
It was in significant decline.
We rebranded it NEXT Pay.
The rebranding didn't make very much difference at all, but all the promotion we did around that has made a significant difference.
Jan 16, our credit customer base was 6% down on the previous year.
As we stand today, our credit customer base is fractionally up on last year, about 0.2% up on last year.
Don't do that wonderful thing of taking your ruler and drawing a straight line and projecting into wonderful growth in our customer -- credit customer base over the next few years.
We think, at best, we will stabilize our credit customer base.
And the reason that we expect this growth to moderate going forward -- and you can see how the line is beginning to flatten as we go from January to July.
And the reason for that is we begin to annualize the point at which we started to promote credit.
So -- and as we reach that point, we're seeing the rates of growth in credit customers moderate.
So we think, at best at the moment, we think just it will hold steady, our credit customer base.

We do have something (inaudible) that I mentioned earlier, by the end of the year, we will have launched at least one new credit product, which we hope will increase the amount of customers who want credit from NEXT.
The personalized homepages.
Very crudely, you saw men's, women's, children's, various customers will get different homepages.
Of the customers who are served personalized homepages, which is only around 40% of our customer base, we see about a 1% improvement in sales, so a fraction of 0.4% across the group.

And I would stress that all of the little changes we made, all the little tweaks we've done, although they're all super-clever and wonderful, of themselves, only give you a fractional increase in sales.
But added together, they seem to have a multiplier effect and are making a significant difference.
Things like, for example, intelligent recommendations.
When you look at an item now, you will see other items that customers who have viewed that item have also viewed.
We now have bags across devices live, which resulted in around 2% reduction in abandoned baskets.
And we've implemented all of these things across our U.K.
site but not overseas.

We prioritized our U.K.
site because it takes the majority of our business.

We're going to do much more to target our e-mails, and much more to target our advertising.

When it comes to all the software that we bought, it was described to me as like someone who's just bought a Ferrari and is driving at a 10 miles an hour around a local supermarket shopping carpark.
